terms.definition: The systematic process of creating, storing, transferring, and utilizing knowledge and information within an organization to improve efficiency and decision-making.
A centralized software platform that organizes, stores, and provides access to an organization's collective knowledge and documentation.
A centralized repository of information, documentation, and resources that provides answers to common questions and solutions to problems.
The capability of a system to create, manage, and display content in multiple languages to serve diverse global audiences.
The ability to view and use digital content without an active internet connection, typically through downloaded or cached data.
The process of developing written, visual, or multimedia materials for documentation, knowledge bases, or other information systems.
The process of sharing expertise, skills, and information from one person, team, or system to another within an organization.
Isolated pockets of information within an organization that are not easily accessible or shared across teams and departments.
The visual and interactive elements of a software application that allow users to interact with and control the system.
Enterprise Resource Planning - integrated software systems that manage and automate core business processes across an organization.
Product Lifecycle Management - software that manages product data and processes throughout a product's entire lifecycle from conception to disposal.
A central storage location where data, documents, or code are organized, managed, and made accessible to authorized users.
The process of integrating new employees into an organization by providing necessary training, resources, and knowledge to become productive.
A customer service metric measuring the percentage of issues resolved during the initial contact without requiring follow-up interactions.
A manufacturing metric that measures the percentage of products or processes that must be corrected or redone due to errors or defects.
